"**I Can Only Imagine** " (sometimes shortened to "**Imagine** ") is a single
recorded by [Christian rock](/wiki/Christian_rock "Christian rock") band
[MercyMe](/wiki/MercyMe "MercyMe"). Written and composed by lead vocalist
[Bart Millard](/wiki/Bart_Millard "Bart Millard"), the song, based around a
main piano track, was inspired by the death of Millard's father and considers
what it would be like in Heaven and to be standing before God. The song was
first issued as a track on MercyMe's 1999 album _[The Worship
Project](/wiki/The_Worship_Project "The Worship Project")_ , which was
released on an independent record label. The song was re-recorded and included
on their 2001 major-label debut album _[Almost
There](/wiki/Almost_There_\(MercyMe_album\) "Almost There \(MercyMe album\)")_
as the fifth song on the album.

"I Can Only Imagine" was released in 2001 as the album's [lead
single](/wiki/Lead_single "Lead single"). It gained significant airplay on
Christian radio formats before crossing over to mainstream radio formats such
as [adult contemporary](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary_music "Adult Contemporary
music") and [Top 40](/wiki/Contemporary_hit_radio "Contemporary hit radio") in
late 2003 and into 2004; to aid in promotion to these markets, a [double
A-side](/wiki/Double_A-side "Double A-side") physical single (combined with
"[Word of God Speak](/wiki/Word_of_God_Speak "Word of God Speak")") was
released in 2003. It charted on several formats, including the
_[Billboard](/wiki/Billboard_\(magazine\) "Billboard \(magazine\)")_ [Adult
Contemporary](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary_\(chart\) "Adult Contemporary
\(chart\)") (where it peaked at No. 5) and the [Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") (where it peaked at No. 71).
In 2002, "I Can Only Imagine" earned the [Dove Awards](/wiki/GMA_Dove_Awards
"GMA Dove Awards") for 'Pop/Contemporary Recorded Song of the Year' and '[Song
of the Year](/wiki/Dove_Award_for_Song_of_the_Year "Dove Award for Song of the
Year")'; Millard earned the Dove Award '[Songwriter of the
Year](/wiki/Dove_Award_for_Songwriter_of_the_Year "Dove Award for Songwriter
of the Year")' at the same ceremony. With 2.5 million copies sold, it is the
best-selling Christian single of all time, having been certified 3x platinum
by the [RIAA](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording
Industry Association of America"). As of 2018, it is the only Christian song
to reach that milestone.

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

"I Can Only Imagine" was the debut single for United States [contemporary
Christian](/wiki/Contemporary_Christian_music "Contemporary Christian music")
and [Christian rock](/wiki/Christian_rock "Christian rock") band
[MercyMe](/wiki/MercyMe "MercyMe"). Bart Millard, the band's vocalist, lost
his father, Arthur Wesley Millard Jr.[1], in 1991. Millard was 18 at the
time.[2][3] Millard began writing the words "I can only imagine" on items when
he was thinking about his father.[4] During the recording of the band's 1999
independent album _[The Worship Project](/wiki/The_Worship_Project "The
Worship Project")_ , MercyMe needed one more song to fill out the album.[5]
Millard, alone on a bus in the middle of the night, finally wrote the lyrics
to the song by drawing on his thoughts and personal faith about what one would
experience standing before God in Heaven. Millard attests that "['I Can Only
Imagine'] is one of the only songs I have ever written where there wasn't any
mistakes, it was just written the way it is and left at that",[5] and
estimated that it took him only ten minutes to write the lyrics.[4]

In writing the music for the song, however, the band faced more difficulty;
Millard noted that "at first it was a fast song... it was all these random
ideas".[5] Keyboardist Jim Bryson noted that, "we were literally tearing down
the stuff... [Millard] and I were talking about arranging it differently and
doing a slower version, so we just tried out a piano intro... it was literally
the first thing I played. It wasn't anything to do with me, I think it was
just a God thing. [Millard] said 'here it is, this is what's going to happen',
and we laid the song down in about five minutes."[5] At that time, the other
MercyMe members were Robby Shaffer on drums and percussion, Nathan Cochran on
bass guitar and Michael Scheuchzer on guitar. This line-up recorded the first
version of the song for _The Worship Project_.[3][6] In 2006, it was included
in the 'Platinum Edition' of _Almost There_.[7]

##
Composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Composition")]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png) |  [I Can Only Imagine](/wiki/File:I_Can_Only_Imagine_2001.ogg "File:I Can Only Imagine 2001.ogg") ![](data:image/png;base64,iVBORw0KGgoAAAANSUhEUgAAAAEAAAABCAQAAAC1HAwCAAAAC0lEQVR42mNkqAcAAIUAgUW0RjgAAAAASUVORK5CYII=)[](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/31/I_Can_Only_Imagine_2001.ogg) A sample of "I Can Only Imagine". [MercyMe](/wiki/MercyMe "MercyMe")'s debut single, "I Can Only Imagine" is "a passionate piano-driven ballad. The song considers what it would be like to be in the presence of God. Delivered with conviction, the song is emotionally compelling".[8]  
---|---  
  
* * *

_Problems playing this file? See[media help](/wiki/Help:Media "Help:Media")._  
  
"I Can Only Imagine" is a [ballad](/wiki/Ballad "Ballad") with a length of
four minutes and eight seconds.[8] The song is set in the key of [E
major](/wiki/E_major "E major") and has a moderately slow [tempo](/wiki/Tempo
"Tempo") of 80 beats per minute with a vocal range from B3–G♯5.[9] The song
opens up with only a piano, and builds up to include guitar and drums.[10]
Millard is credited with both the lyrics and music to the song.[11] The song
was produced by Pete Kipley, who had worked with MercyMe previously[2] as well
as with artists including [Rebecca St. James](/wiki/Rebecca_St._James "Rebecca
St. James"), [Phil Wickham](/wiki/Phil_Wickham "Phil Wickham") and [Lincoln
Brewster](/wiki/Lincoln_Brewster "Lincoln Brewster").[12]

The lyrics to the song are based around the narrator wondering what it will be
like in Heaven and to be standing before God.[8] Regarding this theme, Millard
explained to [Fox News](/wiki/Fox_News "Fox News") that "I was always told
that if he could choose, he would rather be in Heaven than here with me. As a
Christian I believed that, but as an 18-year-old it was a little hard to
swallow. So the questions in the song came from me asking God what was so
great about Him that my dad would rather be there."[2]

## Release and
promotion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Release and promotion")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Bart_Millard_and_Robin_Shaffer_in_concert.JPG/220px-
Bart_Millard_and_Robin_Shaffer_in_concert.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bart_Millard_and_Robin_Shaffer_in_concert.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Bart_Millard_and_Robin_Shaffer_in_concert.JPG "Enlarge")

MercyMe's lead singer-songwriter, Bart Millard (left) and drummer, Robby
Shaffer, performing in February 2008.

"I Can Only Imagine" was re-recorded for their major-label debut record
_Almost There_ and released as its [lead single](/wiki/Lead_single "Lead
single") in 2001.[13] The album was recorded in various locations: Ivy Park,
The Indigo Room, Paradise Sound and IBC Studios.[11] The single gained radio
airplay on some contemporary Christian formats; by November, it peaked at
number-one on the _[Radio& Records](/wiki/Radio_%26_Records "Radio &
Records")_ Christian AC format and in the top twenty of the _Radio & Records_
Christian CHR chart.[14][15]

In 2003, a [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas "Dallas") mainstream radio station, 100.3
Wild-FM, first played the song on its morning show, _The Fitz Radio
Program_.[3][16][17] They had responded to a caller's repeated requests and
the urgings of the program's producer, Todd Sheppard.[2][4] The song soon
became the most requested and most played song on the station.[17][18] After
hearing the song played on the station, Millard called-in and spoke with the
crew; MercyMe then came in and played the song live.[17]

As other stations around the country caught on, MercyMe's label, [INO
Records](/wiki/INO_Records "INO Records"), partnered with [Curb
Records](/wiki/Curb_Records "Curb Records").[17][19][20] They marketed the
single to wider audiences, such as [Top 40 radio](/wiki/Contemporary_hit_radio
"Contemporary hit radio").[19][20][21] In September, INO and Curb also
released a [double A-side](/wiki/Double_A-side "Double A-side") physical
single, "I Can Only Imagine/[Word of God Speak](/wiki/Word_of_God_Speak "Word
of God Speak")".[13] The latter track was co-written by Millard with the
band's producer, Kipley.[22] Eventually, the song cracked into secular charts,
including the [_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot
100")[23] and the [Hot Adult Contemporary
Tracks](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary_\(chart\) "Adult Contemporary \(chart\)")
charts.[24]

##
Impact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Impact")]

MercyMe did not expect "I Can Only Imagine" to gain mainstream success, in
part due to its explicit references to [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus "Jesus") and
[Heaven](/wiki/Heaven "Heaven").[16][17] Millard noted that the band joked
around about "the top five songs never to cross over,[16] and they had
included "I Can Only Imagine" on that list.[16][17] Millard also believed some
radio stations were playing the song to prove it could not succeed on
mainstream radio.[17] The song had a significant effect on the band's musical
image; in an interview, Millard commented that "We were a rock band when we
started 11 years ago. But we kind of became the 'adult contemporary poster
child' when 'I Can Only Imagine' took off".[25]

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Music video")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/92/Imagine_Bart_Millard.PNG/220px-
Imagine_Bart_Millard.PNG)](/wiki/File:Imagine_Bart_Millard.PNG)

[](/wiki/File:Imagine_Bart_Millard.PNG "Enlarge")

Millard holding his father's photograph in the music video.

A music video was released for "I Can Only Imagine".[26][27] Millard recalled
the video's inspiration: "I just kept seeing all these people holding picture
frames [at MercyMe concerts] that are empty because we all carry these people
with us in some way. I've had so many people after a show pull out a picture
of someone they've lost. These people embrace these photos and I just thought
how can we tap into that".[27] The video features everyday people as well as
several music artists including [Michael Tait](/wiki/Michael_Tait "Michael
Tait"), Tammy Trent, [Bob Herdman](/wiki/Bob_Herdman "Bob Herdman"), and
[Jesse Katina](/wiki/The_Katinas "The Katinas"), each holding an empty picture
frame to signify their loss of a loved one; as the video progresses, they are
holding pictures of their loved ones including Millard with his father's
photograph.[27]

The video opens with a shot of an empty room and a chair, shifting to show a
young boy climbing up a flight of stairs. The camera then shifts to the band
before returning to the boy, now in an attic which is filled with many empty
picture frames. The video alternates between shots of the boy and the band
before shifting to individual shots of other people, each holding an empty
picture frame. As the other instruments join in, the camera comes back to the
band, focusing on them before returning to shots of the people, whose picture
frames now contain pictures of deceased relatives. At the end of the video,
the camera returns to the boy, now running down a street with an empty frame,
climaxing with him lying down in a field with the empty frame.[26][27]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Critical response")]

Critical reception for "I Can Only Imagine" was positive. Steve Losey of
[AllMusic](/wiki/AllMusic "AllMusic") commented that "[the song] is a
passionate piano-driven ballad. The song considers what it would be like to be
in the presence of God. Delivered with conviction, the song is emotionally
compelling".[8] Jesus Freak Hideout's reviewer Kevin Chamberlin felt "The
lyrics for the song are amazing. If you haven't listened to the lyrics,
because you're afraid of hearing pop music, get over it and listen to it."[28]
Kevin McNeese of NewReleaseTuesday commented that "The definite highlight on
[_Almost There_] is the worship/ballad 'I Can Only Imagine'... The song starts
out with just piano that instantly invokes chills and builds dynamically into
a powerful display of drums and guitar. But what makes the song are the
lyrics, penned by Bart Millard himself. The song speaks about that day that we
all dream about when we finally meet Jesus... It's a song that can't be
listened to with eyes open".[10]

### Chart
performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Chart performance")]

"I Can Only Imagine" debuted on the _Billboard_ Hot 100 for the chart week of
11 October 2003 at No. 76.[23] The song peaked at No. 71 for two weeks and
spent 16 non-consecutive weeks on the Hot 100.[14][23] On the Adult
Contemporary chart, "I Can Only Imagine" debuted at No. 29 for the chart week
of 23 May 2003, with an eventual peak of No. 5 for the chart week of 8
September 2003; in all, "I Can Only Imagine" spent 30 weeks on the
chart.[14][24]

On the [Adult Top 40](/wiki/Adult_Top_40 "Adult Top 40") chart, "I Can Only
Imagine" debuted at No. 39 for the chart week of 9 August 2003 and reached a
peak position of No. 27, holding that spot for three consecutive weeks; in
all, the song spent 26 weeks on the chart.[14][29] On the [Mainstream Top
40](/wiki/Mainstream_Top_40_\(Pop_Songs\) "Mainstream Top 40 \(Pop Songs\)")
chart, the song debuted at No. 37 for the chart week of 12 July 2003, reaching
an eventual peak of No. 33.[14][30] On the [Country
Songs](/wiki/Hot_Country_Songs "Hot Country Songs") chart, the song debuted at
No. 58 for the chart week of 27 December 2003, reaching an eventual peak of
No. 52, which it held for two weeks.[31] According to [Mike
Curb](/wiki/Mike_Curb "Mike Curb") on the Curb Records website, "I Can Only
Imagine" also peaked at No. 1 on the _Billboard_ [Hot 100 Singles
Sales](/wiki/Hot_Singles_Sales "Hot Singles Sales") chart for 10 weeks, No. 1
on the _[Radio& Records](/wiki/Radio_%26_Records "Radio & Records")_ Christian
AC chart for two weeks,[14][15] and No. 15 on the Christian CHR chart.[14]

In April 2010, "I Can Only Imagine" was [certified
platinum](/wiki/RIAA_certification "RIAA certification") by the
[RIAA](/wiki/Recording_Industry_Association_of_America "Recording Industry
Association of America"), signifying sales of over 1,000,000 digital
downloads.[32] It is the first single by any artist in the Christian music
genre to go platinum.[33] The song was certified 2x platinum in 2014.[32] It
was certified 3x platinum in 2018.[34] As of June 2018, it has sold 3 million
copies, making it the best-selling Christian single of all time.[35][36]

### Awards and
accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Awards and accolades")]

"I Can Only Imagine" earned two [GMA Dove Awards](/wiki/GMA_Dove_Award "GMA
Dove Award") in 2002; 'Pop/Contemporary Recorded Song of the Year' and '[Song
of the Year](/wiki/Dove_Award_for_Song_of_the_Year "Dove Award for Song of the
Year")'.[37][38] Millard also won '[Songwriter of the
Year](/wiki/Dove_Award_for_Songwriter_of_the_Year "Dove Award for Songwriter
of the Year")' at the same ceremony.[37][38] In November 2009, the song was
played on board [Space Shuttle _Atlantis_](/wiki/Space_Shuttle_Atlantis "Space
Shuttle Atlantis") as a wake-up call for [Barry E.
Wilmore](/wiki/Barry_E._Wilmore "Barry E. Wilmore") during
[STS-129](/wiki/STS-129 "STS-129").[39]

## Other
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Other versions")]

The original version of "I Can Only Imagine" was a track on MercyMe's 1999
independent release _The Worship Project_.[6] In August 2006, both an acoustic
and live form (as well as the original 1999 version) were included in the
'Platinum edition' of _Almost There_.[7] MercyMe recorded a version of the
song for their _[iTunes Originals](/wiki/ITunes_Originals "ITunes Originals")_
album.[40][41] In 2009, two further variants were included on their
compilation album _[10](/wiki/10_\(MercyMe_album\) "10 \(MercyMe album\)")_ ;
a 'symphony version' featuring the [London Symphony
Orchestra](/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra "London Symphony Orchestra"), and a
live version.[42]

"I Can Only Imagine" has also been covered by several artists.[43] In 2002
[Amy Grant](/wiki/Amy_Grant "Amy Grant") released a reworked version of the
song (titled "Imagine" and paired with "Sing the Wondrous Love of Jesus") on
her album, _[Legacy... Hymns and Faith](/wiki/Legacy..._Hymns_and_Faith
"Legacy... Hymns and Faith")_.[44] In 2003, [Jeff Carson](/wiki/Jeff_Carson
"Jeff Carson") and [Kathryn Scott](/wiki/Kathryn_Sarah_Scott "Kathryn Sarah
Scott") each issued variants of the song;[44][45] Carson's version peaked at
No. 50 on the Country Songs chart.[46] In 2005 [Wynonna
Judd](/wiki/Wynonna_Judd "Wynonna Judd") issued her form of the song;[44]
while in 2007 [Emerson Drive](/wiki/Emerson_Drive "Emerson Drive") provided
theirs.[47] The song was covered again in 2010 by [Marie
Osmond](/wiki/Marie_Osmond "Marie Osmond") and in 2013 by gospel artist Tamela
Mann.

The song was performed live by Garwin Dobbins, a man struggling with
[fibrodysplasia ossificans
progressiva](/wiki/Fibrodysplasia_ossificans_progressiva "Fibrodysplasia
ossificans progressiva"), a crippling disease referred to as Stone Man's
syndrome, in which the body's repair mechanism replaces muscle with bone,
causing many joints to become permanently frozen in place.[48] Dobbins, who
died in 2004, sang the song on a broadcast of Austin Awakening, accompanied by
pastor Randy Phillips of [Phillips, Craig and
Dean](/wiki/Phillips,_Craig_and_Dean "Phillips, Craig and Dean"). Footage of
the performance was featured in the finale of the Trevor Glass documentary
"Suffer the Children."[49] There is also a German version "Ich kann nur davon
träumen".

## Film
adaptation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(MercyMe_song\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Film adaptation")]

Main article: [I Can Only Imagine (film)](/wiki/I_Can_Only_Imagine_\(film\) "I
Can Only Imagine \(film\)")

The story behind the song was made into a feature film starring J. Michael
Finley and [Dennis Quaid](/wiki/Dennis_Quaid "Dennis Quaid"). The film was
released on March 16, 2018.
